Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Communicate and offer small mutual help like receiving packages or checking in during emergencies
Situation2: A delivery is expected this afternoon while I will be at home and the neighbor often misses packages.
Story:
I stared at the group chat on my phone, my stepmom’s message blinking at the top: “Don’t forget, we’re all meeting at Grandma’s at 2 for the holiday lunch. It means a lot to your dad and me that you’re there.” I knew how important these family gatherings were, especially since I was still finding my place as a step-sibling. I wanted to show I cared, to be part of the family, even if it sometimes felt awkward.

But then my phone buzzed again—this time, a text from Mrs. Lee next door. “Hi! Could you please keep an eye out for a package this afternoon? I’m working late and it’s really important.” She’d helped me out before, watering my plants and checking my mail when I was away. I felt responsible, like I owed her this small favor.

The clock ticked closer to two. If I left for Grandma’s, I’d miss the delivery window. If I stayed, I’d disappoint my new family. My stomach twisted as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides, wishing I could be in two places at once.
